text: Space has a distinct smell - astronauts describe it as a bouquet of diesel fumes, gunpowder, and barbecue, mostly produced by dying stars.
Russian cosmonauts used to pack a shotgun in case they landed in Siberia - for protection against bears.
Apollo 17 astronaut Harrison Schmitt was allergic to moon dust - it caused the inside of his nose to swell and affected his throat.
A solar eclipse helped end a six-year war in 585 BCE - when the sky suddenly darkened during a battle between the Lydians and the Medes, soldiers took it as a sign to cease fighting.
Mercury's surface has mysterious bright streaks that appear to be caused by very recent geological activity - the 'dead' planet may still be geologically active after 4.5 billion years.

Space news, features and articles Space is a seemingly infinite world of wonder and discovery, filled with mysterious black holes , stunning solar flares , elusive exoplanets and countless cosmic oddities .

GCIRS 13E is one of the most massive known stars at approximately 1,300 solar masses - so massive it defies current stellar models.
Earth orbits the Sun at approximately 107,200 km/h (67,000 mph), completing one revolution every 365.25 days.
Venus has a surface temperature of 464°C - hotter than Mercury despite being farther from the Sun, due to its runaway greenhouse effect.
Mercury's surface temperature swings from 700°C during the day to -180°C at night - the most extreme temperature variation in the solar system.
Melnick 42 is a hypergiant star approximately 189 times the mass of our Sun, located in the Large Magellanic Cloud.
LBV 1806-20 is a luminous blue variable star approximately 165 solar masses - one of the most massive stars known.
Earth maintains an average temperature of 15°C, making it the only planet known to support liquid water on its surface.
Mars experiences temperatures ranging from 35°C to -143°C, with an average of -63°C.
UY Scuti is one of the largest known stars, with a radius approximately 1,700 times that of our Sun.
Earendel is the most distant individual star ever detected, located approximately 12.9 billion light-years from Earth.
NML Cygni is a red hypergiant star with a radius 1,642 times that of the Sun - if placed at the Sun's position, it would engulf Jupiter's orbit.
Rho Cassiopeiae is a yellow hypergiant star 40 times the mass of our Sun that pulses irregularly, changing brightness dramatically.
AG Carinae is a luminous blue variable star 55 times the mass of our Sun and one of the most luminous stars in the Milky Way.
Shenzhou 13 was launched in 2021 by China Aerospace Science and Technology Corporation.
Shenzhou 15 was launched in 2022 by China National Space Administration.
Korabl-Sputnik 5 was launched in 1961 by Soviet space program.
Korabl-Sputnik 5 was launched in 1961 by Academy of Sciences of the USSR.
BelKA was launched in 2006 by National Academy of Sciences of Belarus.
STSAT-2A was launched in 2009 by Korea Aerospace Research Institute.
Intermediate eXperimental Vehicle was launched in 2015 by European Space Agency.
European Space Research Organization 1A was launched in 1968.
Gravity Probe A was launched in 1976 by National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
SDS-4 was launched in 2012 by Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency.
UK-DMC was launched in 2003 by British National Space Centre.
Myojo was launched in 1994 by National Space Development Agency.
Lixing 1 was launched in 2016 by Chinese Academy of Sciences.
Solrad 8 was launched in 1965 by National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
Mengtian was launched in 2022 by China National Space Administration.
The comet C/1975 T2 (Suzuki–Saigusa–Mori) was independently discovered by five observers within the span of half an hour.
More than one hundred million stars are visible in NASA's 'Zooming In on the Andromeda Galaxy' image.
In fiction, neutron stars harbour exotic lifeforms in their vicinity, on their surface, and even in their interior.
The first dogs in space (Dezik and Tsygan) returned to Earth with a parachute.
The 1827 novel 'A Voyage to the Moon' contains the first use of anti-gravity for space travel in science fiction.
As of 1.06 billion years ago, three supermassive black holes from a trio of galaxies in the constellation of Cancer were colliding.
Although J1407b eclipsed V1400 Centauri in 2007, nobody noticed for over three years.
Apollo astronauts walked on walls (Reduced Gravity Walking Simulator) before walking on the Moon.
The two victims of the Zénith balloon incident are depicted holding hands on their tomb.
This list covers all known stars, white dwarfs, brown dwarfs, and sub-brown dwarfs/rogue planets within 20 light-years (6.13 parsecs) of the Sun.

Only 22 are bright enough to be visible without a telescope, for which the star's visible light needs to reach or exceed the dimmest brightness visible to the naked eye from Earth, which is typically around 6.5 apparent magnitude.
Of those, 103 are main sequence stars: 80 red dwarfs and 23 "typical" stars having greater mass.
Additionally, astronomers have found 6 white dwarfs (stars that have exhausted all fusible hydrogen), 21 brown dwarfs, as well as 1 sub-brown dwarf, WISE 0855−0714 (possibly a rogue planet).
The closest system is Alpha Centauri, with Proxima Centauri as the closest star in that system, at 4.2465 light-years from Earth.

The brightest, most massive and most luminous object among those 131 is Sirius A, which is also the brightest star in Earth's night sky; its white dwarf companion Sirius B is the hottest object among them.
The largest object within the 20 light-years is Procyon.
The Solar System, and the other stars/dwarfs listed here, are currently moving within (or near) the Local Interstellar Cloud, roughly 30 light-years (9.2 pc) across.
The Local Interstellar Cloud is, in turn, contained inside the Local Bubble, a cavity in the interstellar medium about 300 light-years (92.0 pc) across.
It contains Ursa Major and the Hyades star cluster, among others.
The Local Bubble also contains the neighboring G-Cloud, which contains the stars Alpha Centauri and Altair.
In the galactic context, the Local Bubble is a small part of the Orion Arm, which contains most stars that we can see without a telescope.

As a parsec (parallax-second) is defined by the distance of an object that would appear to move exactly one second of arc against background objects, stars less than 5 parsecs away will have measured parallaxes of over 0.2 arcseconds, or 200 milliarcseconds.

Both of these measurements are subject to increasing and significant errors over very long time spans, especially over the several thousand-year time spans it takes for stars to noticeably move relative to each other.
Based on results from the Gaia telescope's second data release from April 2018, an estimated 694 stars will approach the Solar System to less than 5 parsecs in the next 15 million years.
The closest encounter to the Sun so far predicted is the low-mass orange dwarf star Gliese 710 / HIP 89825 with roughly 60% the mass of the Sun.
Many brown dwarfs are not listed by visual magnitude but are listed by near-infrared J band apparent magnitude due to how dim (and often invisible) they are in visible color bands (U, B or V).
Absolute magnitude (with electromagnetic wave, 'light' band denoted in subscript) is a measurement at a 10-parsec distance across imaginary empty space devoid of all its sparse dust and gas.

This can cause other currently distant stars to fall within a stated range, which may be readily calculated and predicted using accurate astrometric measurements of parallax and total proper motions, along with spectroscopically determined radial velocities.
Although extrapolations can be made into the past or future, they are subject to increasingly significant cumulative errors over very long periods.
Inaccuracies of these measured parameters make determining the true minimum distances of any encountering stars or brown dwarfs fairly difficult.
One of the first stars known to approach the Sun particularly close is Gliese 710.
The star, whose mass is roughly half that of the Sun, is currently 62 light-years from the Solar System.
Physical Properties of ~ 1000 Cool Stars from the SPOCS Catalog".
Table 4 "The Census of Stars and Brown Dwarfs within 8 Parsecs of the Sun" in Bailer-Jones, C.
This is a list of the most massive stars that have been discovered, in solar mass units (M☉).
Indeed, many of the masses listed in the table below are inferred from theory, using difficult measurements of the stars' temperatures, composition, and absolute brightnesses.
All the listed stars are many thousands of light years away making their light especially faint, which makes measurements difficult.

In addition to being far away, many stars of such extreme mass are surrounded by clouds of outflowing gas created by extremely powerful stellar winds; the surrounding gas interferes with the already difficult-to-obtain measurements of stellar temperatures and brightnesses, which greatly complicates the issue of estimating internal chemical compositions and structures.
This obscuration leads to difficulties in determining the parameters needed to calculate the star's mass.
Both the obscuring clouds and the great distances also make it difficult to judge whether the star is just a single supermassive object or, instead, a multiple star system.

A number of the "stars" listed below may actually be two or more companions orbiting too closely for our telescopes to distinguish, each star possibly being massive in itself but not necessarily "supermassive" to either be on this list, or near the top of it.

And certainly other combinations are possible – for example a supermassive star with one or more smaller companions or more than one giant star – but without being able to clearly see inside the surrounding cloud, it is difficult to know  what kind of object is actually generating the bright point of light seen from the Earth.
However, note that almost all of the masses listed in the table below were inferred by indirect methods; only a few of the masses in the table were determined using eclipsing systems.

The radial velocities only yield minimum values for the masses, depending on inclination, but light curves of eclipsing binaries provide the missing information: inclination of the orbit to our line of sight.
Many large stars have likely suffered significant mass loss – perhaps as much as several tens of solar masses.

The process forms an enlarged extended envelope around the star that interacts with the nearby interstellar medium and infuses the adjacent volume of space with elements heavier than hydrogen or helium.
There are also – or rather were – stars that might have appeared on the list but no longer exist as stars, or are supernova impostors; today we see only their debris.
The masses of the precursor stars that fueled these destructive events can be estimated from the type of explosion and the energy released, but those masses are not listed here.
This list only concerns "living" stars – those which are still seen by Earth-based observers existing as active stars: Still engaged in interior nuclear fusion that generates heat and light.

That is, the light now arriving at the Earth as images of the stars listed still shows them to internally generate new energy as of the time (in the distant past) that light now being received was emitted.

The accretion limit is related to star formation: After about 120 M☉ have accreted in a protostar, the combined mass should have become hot enough for its heat to drive away any further incoming matter.
In effect, the protostar reaches a temperature where it evaporates away material already collected as fast as it collects new material.

The Eddington limit is based on light pressure from the core of an already-formed star: As mass increases past ~150 M☉, the intensity of light radiated from a Population I star's core will become sufficient for the light-pressure pushing outward to exceed the gravitational force pulling inward, and the surface material of the star will be free to float away into space.
Since their different compositions make them more transparent, Population II and Population III stars have higher and much higher mass limits, respectively.

Although the limit can be stretched for very early Population III stars, and although the exact value is uncertain, if any stars still exist above 150~200 M☉ they would challenge current theories of stellar evolution.
Studying the Arches Cluster, which is currently the densest known cluster of stars in our galaxy, astronomers have confirmed that no stars in that cluster exceed about 150 M☉.

Rare ultramassive stars that exceed this limit – for example in the R136 star cluster – might be explained by an exceptional event hypothesized to have occurred: some of the pairs of massive stars in close orbit in young, unstable multiple-star systems must, on rare occasions, collide and merge when certain unusual circumstances hold that make a collision possible.
The lowest mass for which this effect is active is the Eddington limit.
Stars of greater mass have a higher rate of core energy generation, and heavier stars' luminosities increase far out of proportion to the increase in their masses.
The Eddington limit is the point beyond which a star ought to push itself apart, or at least shed enough mass to reduce its internal energy generation to a lower, sustainable rate.
The actual limit-point mass depends on how opaque the gas in the star is, and metal-rich Population I stars have lower mass limits than metal-poor Population II stars.
Before their demise, the hypothetical metal-free Population III stars would have had the highest allowed mass, somewhere around 300 M☉.
In theory, a more massive star could not hold itself together because of the mass loss resulting from the outflow of stellar material.
In practice the theoretical Eddington Limit must be modified for high luminosity stars and the empirical Humphreys–Davidson limit is used instead.
Stars that are at least sometimes visible to the unaided eye have their apparent magnitude (6.5 or brighter) highlighted with a sky blue background.
The first list gives stars that are estimated to be 60 M☉ or larger; the majority of which are shown.
The second list includes some notable stars which are below 60 M☉ for the purpose of comparison.
The method used to determine each star's mass is included to give an idea of the data's uncertainty; note that the mass of binary stars can be determined far more accurately.
The masses listed below are the stars' current (evolved) mass, not their initial (formation) mass.

A few notable large stars with masses less than 60 M☉ are shown in the table below for the purpose of comparison, ending with the Sun, which is very close, but would otherwise be too small to be included in the list.
Technically they are not stars, as they no longer generate heat and light via nuclear fusion in their cores.
Some black holes may have cosmological origins, and would then never have been stars.
Stellar black holes are objects with approximately 4–15 M☉ .
Supermassive black holes are in the range of millions or billions M☉.
Neutron stars are so dense that a teaspoon of their material would weigh about 6 billion tons on Earth.
The observable universe contains about 2 trillion galaxies, but due to the universe's expansion, we can only ever reach about 3% of them.
The Sun loses about 4 million tons of mass every second through nuclear fusion, yet has enough fuel to burn for another 5 billion years.
If the Sun were the size of a white blood cell and the Milky Way were scaled down proportionally, our galaxy would still be the size of the continental United States.
There's a giant cloud of alcohol in space called Sagittarius B2 that contains enough ethyl alcohol to fill 400 trillion trillion pints of beer.
The Voyager 1 spacecraft, launched in 1977, is now so far from Earth that its radio signals take over 22 hours to reach us.
A day on Venus is longer than its year — it takes 243 Earth days to rotate once but only 225 Earth days to orbit the Sun.
The largest known star, UY Scuti, is so massive that if placed at the center of our solar system, its surface would extend beyond the orbit of Jupiter.
The Great Attractor is pulling our galaxy and millions of others toward it at 600 km/s, but we can't see what it is because our own galaxy blocks our view.
Olympus Mons on Mars is so large that if you stood on its peak, the mountain would extend past the horizon — you wouldn't know you were on a mountain.
The coldest known place in the universe isn't in deep space — it's the Boomerang Nebula at -272°C, colder than the cosmic microwave background.
The Pistol Star releases more energy in 20 seconds than our Sun does in an entire year.
There are more trees on Earth than stars in the Milky Way — approximately 3 trillion trees compared to 100-400 billion stars.
A magnetar's magnetic field is so powerful that it could erase your credit cards from half the distance between Earth and the Moon.
Saturn's density is so low that if you could find a bathtub big enough, the planet would float in water.
The cosmic microwave background radiation is the oldest light in the universe, released 380,000 years after the Big Bang when the universe first became transparent.
The largest structure in the known universe is the Hercules-Corona Borealis Great Wall, spanning about 10 billion light-years.
Gamma-ray bursts are so energetic that if one occurred 1,000 light-years from Earth, it could cause a mass extinction.
Light from some distant galaxies we observe today was emitted when the universe was only 400 million years old.
The core of Jupiter is so hot and pressurized that hydrogen becomes a liquid metal that conducts electricity.
The Wow! signal, detected in 1977, remains unexplained — a strong narrowband radio signal that lasted 72 seconds and matched the expected signature of extraterrestrial intelligence.
The Moon is slowly drifting away from Earth at about 3.8 cm per year, and in about 600 million years, total solar eclipses will no longer be possible.
The Parker Solar Probe will reach speeds of 430,000 mph, making it the fastest human-made object ever created.
The most distant galaxy ever observed, JADES-GS-z14-0, is so far away that we see it as it was just 290 million years after the Big Bang.
Neutron stars can spin up to 716 times per second — at their equator, the surface moves at about 24% the speed of light.
There's a planet made of diamond — 55 Cancri e is thought to be composed largely of crystallized carbon.
The Sun's core fuses 620 million metric tons of hydrogen into helium every second.
Betelgeuse, visible in Orion, could go supernova tomorrow or in 100,000 years — when it does, it will be visible in daylight for weeks.
Europa, Jupiter's moon, has more water than all of Earth's oceans combined, hidden beneath its icy surface.
There are rogue planets wandering through space not bound to any star — there may be billions of them in our galaxy alone.

Pluto takes 248 Earth years to orbit the Sun.
Saturn's rings are only about 10 meters thick on average, despite being 282,000 km wide.
The Sun loses about 4 million tons of mass every second through nuclear fusion.
Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun but not the hottest - that's Venus.
Mars has the largest dust storms in the solar system, lasting for months.
Uranus rotates on its side, with its axis tilted at 98 degrees.
The asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter contains millions of asteroids.
The Sun accounts for 99.86% of all mass in our solar system.
Ganymede, Jupiter's largest moon, is bigger than the planet Mercury.
The hottest planet in our solar system is Venus at 475°C (887°F).
The Olympus Mons volcano on Mars is nearly three times the height of Mount Everest.
The core of the Sun reaches temperatures of about 15 million degrees Celsius.
The distance from Earth to the Moon is increasing by about 3.8 cm per year.
The Moon is about 4.5 billion years old, roughly the same age as Earth.
Jupiter's moon Europa likely has an ocean under its icy surface with more water than Earth.
The largest known black hole has a mass of 40 billion suns.
Saturn's density is so low it would float in water if you could find a big enough pool.
Neptune has the strongest winds in the solar system, reaching speeds of 1,200 mph.
The Andromeda Galaxy is on a collision course with the Milky Way, expected in 4.5 billion years.
The solar system is about 4.6 billion years old.
The universe is expanding faster than the speed of light at its edges.
The Sun will become a red giant in about 5 billion years, possibly engulfing Earth.
The Milky Way takes about 225 million years to complete one rotation.
The first photograph of a black hole was taken in 2019.
Neutron stars can spin up to 716 times per second.
The tallest mountain in our solar system is Olympus Mons on Mars at 72,000 feet.
A photon of light would take 100,000 years to cross the Milky Way galaxy.
The universe is approximately 13.8 billion years old.
The light we see from the Andromeda Galaxy left there 2.5 million years ago.
The farthest galaxy ever observed is GN-z11, at 13.4 billion light-years away.
The smallest known exoplanet is Kepler-37b, about the size of Earth's Moon.
Supermassive black holes at the centers of galaxies can have billions of solar masses.
The observable universe has a diameter of about 93 billion light-years.
The cosmic microwave background radiation is the oldest light in the universe.
Dark energy makes up about 68% of the universe.
Dark matter makes up about 27% of the universe but has never been directly observed.
Pulsars are rotating neutron stars that emit beams of radiation.
Quasars are the brightest objects in the universe, powered by supermassive black holes.
White dwarfs are the remnants of Sun-like stars and can stay hot for billions of years.
Magnetars are neutron stars with magnetic fields trillions of times stronger than Earth's.
A teaspoon of matter from a neutron star would weigh about 6 billion tons.
The most distant object visible to the naked eye is the Andromeda Galaxy.
Gamma-ray bursts are the most energetic explosions in the universe.
Red giant stars can be over 100 times larger than the Sun.
Binary stars are two stars orbiting a common center of mass.
Yuri Gagarin became the first human in space on April 12, 1961.
The first human-made object to leave the solar system was Voyager 1 in 2012.
Brown dwarfs are 'failed stars' too small to sustain nuclear fusion.
Neil Armstrong's first step on the Moon was on July 20, 1969.
Exoplanets are planets that orbit stars outside our solar system.
The International Space Station has been continuously occupied since 2000.
Protoplanetary disks are clouds of gas and dust where planets form.
The Hubble Space Telescope has been operating since 1990.
Stellar nurseries are regions of space where new stars are born.
The Mars rovers Spirit and Opportunity far outlasted their 90-day mission.
Planetary nebulae are shells of gas ejected by dying stars.
The Space Shuttle program flew 135 missions between 1981 and 2011.
The Oort Cloud is a theoretical shell of icy objects at the solar system's edge.
SpaceX launched the first private crewed mission to space in 2020.
The Kuiper Belt contains Pluto and many other icy bodies.
The James Webb Space Telescope launched in 2021 and observes infrared light.
Asteroids in the main belt orbit between Mars and Jupiter.
Sputnik 1 was the first artificial satellite, launched in 1957.
Comets develop tails when they approach the Sun due to solar radiation.
Laika the dog was the first animal to orbit Earth, in 1957.
Meteor showers occur when Earth passes through comet debris trails.
The first space station was Salyut 1, launched by the Soviet Union in 1971.
Zodiacal light is caused by sunlight reflecting off interplanetary dust.
The Apollo program landed 12 astronauts on the Moon between 1969 and 1972.
The Milky Way has a supermassive black hole called Sagittarius A* at its center.
Valentina Tereshkova became the first woman in space in 1963.
Variable stars change brightness over time, sometimes predictably.
The Voyager Golden Records contain sounds and images of Earth for any alien finders.
Ecliptic is the plane in which Earth orbits the Sun.
Alexei Leonov performed the first spacewalk in 1965.
Parallax is the apparent shift of a star's position as Earth orbits the Sun.
The first GPS satellite was launched in 1978.
Cepheid variables are stars used to measure cosmic distances.
The Mir space station was continuously occupied for almost 10 years.
Light pollution affects astronomical observations from Earth.
The Curiosity rover has been exploring Mars since 2012.
Redshift indicates how fast distant galaxies are moving away from us.
The New Horizons probe flew by Pluto in 2015 after a 9-year journey.
The Hertzsprung-Russell diagram plots stars by temperature and luminosity.
The Perseverance rover landed on Mars in 2021 to search for signs of ancient life.
The Sun will exhaust its hydrogen fuel in about 5 billion years.
Cassini orbited Saturn for 13 years, providing unprecedented views of the planet.
Radio telescopes detect radio waves from space invisible to optical telescopes.
The Ingenuity helicopter was the first aircraft to fly on another planet.
Adaptive optics correct for atmospheric distortion in ground-based telescopes.
The Huygens probe landed on Saturn's moon Titan in 2005.
Spectroscopy reveals the chemical composition of distant stars.
The Dawn spacecraft orbited both Vesta and Ceres in the asteroid belt.
Interferometry combines multiple telescopes for higher resolution observations.
OSIRIS-REx collected samples from asteroid Bennu and returned them to Earth.
The first private citizen to travel to space was Dennis Tito in 2001.
Astrometry measures the positions and movements of celestial objects.
The Juno spacecraft has been studying Jupiter since 2016.
Coronagraphs block out starlight to reveal orbiting exoplanets.
The Parker Solar Probe is the closest human-made object to the Sun.
The transit method detects exoplanets by observing dips in starlight.
The Artemis program aims to return humans to the Moon.
Radial velocity detects exoplanets by measuring stellar wobble.
SpaceX's Starship is designed to be fully reusable for Mars missions.
Direct imaging captures actual photos of exoplanets around other stars.
Blue Origin's New Shepard is designed for space tourism.
Gravitational microlensing can detect exoplanets by observing light bending.
The first commercial spacewalk was performed by SpaceX's Polaris Dawn mission.
The Gaia spacecraft is mapping a billion stars in the Milky Way.
Virgin Galactic offers suborbital space tourism flights.
The TESS mission searches for exoplanets around nearby bright stars.
China's Tiangong space station has been continuously occupied since 2022.
The JWST can detect the atmospheres of exoplanets for signs of life.
India's Chandrayaan-3 successfully landed near the Moon's south pole in 2023.
The habitable zone is the region around a star where liquid water can exist.
Japan's Hayabusa2 returned samples from asteroid Ryugu in 2020.
Biosignatures are signs of life detectable in exoplanet atmospheres.
The first all-civilian crew to orbit Earth was SpaceX's Inspiration4 mission.
Technosignatures are potential signs of alien technology.
The Lucy mission is exploring Jupiter's Trojan asteroids.
The SETI Institute searches for extraterrestrial intelligence using radio telescopes.
The Europa Clipper mission will study Jupiter's moon for signs of habitability.
The Drake equation estimates the number of communicating civilizations in the galaxy.
The Dragonfly mission will send a drone to Saturn's moon Titan.
The Fermi Paradox asks why we haven't detected alien civilizations.
NASA's DART mission successfully changed an asteroid's orbit in 2022.
Extremophiles on Earth show life can survive in harsh conditions.
The Vera C. Rubin Observatory will survey the entire visible sky repeatedly.
Panspermia is the hypothesis that life can spread between planets.
The Roman Space Telescope will study dark energy and exoplanets.
Water bears (tardigrades) have survived exposure to outer space.
The Extremely Large Telescope will be the world's largest optical telescope.
The building blocks of life have been found in meteorites and comets.
The Square Kilometre Array will be the world's largest radio telescope.
Mars once had liquid water on its surface billions of years ago.
The Giant Magellan Telescope will have resolving power 10 times Hubble's.
Europa's subsurface ocean may contain more water than all of Earth's oceans.
The Thirty Meter Telescope will observe the universe with unprecedented detail.
Enceladus, Saturn's moon, has geysers that may harbor life.
The Event Horizon Telescope imaged the shadow of a black hole.
Titan has lakes of liquid methane and ethane on its surface.
Very Long Baseline Interferometry connects telescopes across continents.
Amino acids have been found in interstellar space.
The Cherenkov Telescope Array will study high-energy gamma rays.
The Miller-Urey experiment showed organic molecules can form naturally.
The CHIME telescope detected the first known repeating fast radio burst.
RNA world hypothesis suggests life began with self-replicating RNA.
The Atacama Large Millimeter Array studies cold gas and dust in space.
Phosphine detected in Venus's atmosphere sparked debate about possible life.
The South Pole Telescope studies the cosmic microwave background.
Shadow biospheres may contain life forms using different biochemistry.
The Arecibo message was sent to star cluster M13 in 1974.
Some scientists believe viruses may have originated in space.
LIGO detected the first gravitational waves from merging black holes.
The ocean floor may host unique extremophile ecosystems.
The IceCube Neutrino Observatory detects neutrinos from space.
Life may exist in the subsurface oceans of icy moons.
Fast radio bursts are mysterious millisecond pulses from deep space.
Chemosynthesis allows life to exist without sunlight at ocean vents.
Neutron star mergers produce heavy elements like gold and platinum.
Lithopanspermia is the transfer of life via meteorites between planets.
The first exoplanet around a Sun-like star was discovered in 1995.
Deep subsurface bacteria may live miles underground.
Kepler discovered over 2,600 exoplanets before being retired.
Radiation-resistant bacteria could potentially survive on Mars.
The first multi-planet system was discovered around pulsar PSR B1257+12.
Some archaea can survive in acid with pH near 0.
The first Earth-sized exoplanet in a habitable zone was Kepler-186f.
Halophiles thrive in extremely salty environments like salt lakes.
TRAPPIST-1 has seven Earth-sized planets, three in the habitable zone.
Thermophiles live in temperatures above 140°F at hot springs.
Proxima Centauri b is the nearest known exoplanet to Earth.
Psychrophiles survive in permanently frozen environments.
LHS 1140 b may be a rocky super-Earth in its star's habitable zone.
Barophiles thrive under extreme pressure in deep ocean trenches.
GJ 667C c was once considered a potentially habitable exoplanet.
Methanogens produce methane and could survive on Mars.
Ross 128 b is one of the closest temperate exoplanets to Earth.
Oligotrophs can survive with minimal nutrients.
Tau Ceti has multiple planet candidates in its habitable zone.
Endoliths live inside rocks and can survive for millennia.
Wolf 1061c is a rocky exoplanet in its star's habitable zone.
Xerophiles can survive in extremely dry conditions.
Kapteyn b is one of the oldest known potentially habitable exoplanets.
Cryoprotectants allow some organisms to survive being frozen.
Gliese 581g is a disputed exoplanet in the habitable zone.
Anoxygenic photosynthesis doesn't produce oxygen.
HD 40307 g is a super-Earth in its star's habitable zone.
Radiation-resistant enzymes may function on other planets.
Kepler-442b has the highest Earth Similarity Index of known exoplanets.
Some bacteria can survive intense UV radiation.
K2-18b may have water vapor in its atmosphere.
TOI 700 d is an Earth-sized exoplanet in the habitable zone.
Teegarden's Star b is one of the most Earth-like exoplanets known.
The first confirmed rogue planet was discovered in 2011.
Hot Jupiters are gas giants orbiting very close to their stars.
Super-Earths are rocky planets larger than Earth but smaller than Neptune.
Mini-Neptunes are exoplanets between Earth and Neptune in size.
Ocean worlds may be common in the outer solar system.
Circumbinary planets orbit two stars.
Trojan asteroids share Jupiter's orbit around the Sun.
Dwarf planets like Pluto are too small to clear their orbital neighborhood.
Centaurs are small bodies between Jupiter and Neptune.
Trans-Neptunian objects orbit beyond Neptune.
The Oort Cloud may contain trillions of icy objects.
Interstellar objects like 'Oumuamua visit our solar system.
Borisov was the first confirmed interstellar comet.
Scattered disc objects are icy bodies beyond the Kuiper Belt.
Planetary rings are made of dust, ice, and rock particles.
Solar flares can disrupt communications on Earth.
Coronal mass ejections can cause geomagnetic storms.
The solar wind carries charged particles throughout the solar system.
Sunspots are cooler regions on the Sun's surface.
The Sun's corona is visible during a total solar eclipse.
Helioseismology studies the Sun's interior using sound waves.
Solar prominences are loops of plasma erupting from the Sun.
The heliopause is the boundary where solar wind meets interstellar space.
The termination shock is where solar wind slows to subsonic speed.
Voyager 1 crossed the heliopause in 2012.
Voyager 2 crossed into interstellar space in 2018.
The heliosphere protects the solar system from cosmic radiation.
Asteroseismology studies stellar interiors through oscillations.
Stellar wind carries mass away from stars.
Wolf-Rayet stars are massive stars with intense stellar winds.
Luminous blue variables are among the most massive stars known.
Betelgeuse is a red supergiant star that may explode soon.
Rigel is a blue supergiant star 79 times the Sun's diameter.
Antares is a red supergiant 700 times the Sun's diameter.
Deneb is a white supergiant 200 times the Sun's diameter.
Polaris is the North Star and a Cepheid variable.
Vega was the first star other than the Sun to be photographed.
Arcturus is an orange giant star 25 times the Sun's diameter.
Aldebaran is an orange giant star 44 times the Sun's diameter.
Spica is a binary star system with two blue giants.
Sirius is the brightest star in the night sky.
Canopus is the second brightest star after Sirius.
Alpha Centauri is the closest star system to our Sun.
Proxima Centauri is the closest individual star to the Sun.
Barnard's Star is the fastest-moving star relative to the Sun.
Wolf 359 is one of the nearest stars to the Sun.
Lalande 21185 is a red dwarf visible from the Northern Hemisphere.
Epsilon Eridani is one of the nearest Sun-like stars.
61 Cygni was the first star to have its distance measured.
Groombridge 34 is a binary star system 11.6 light-years away.
Ross 248 will be the closest star to the Sun in 36,000 years.
Lacaille 9352 is a red dwarf in the southern constellation Piscis Austrinus.
Ross 154 is a red dwarf flare star 9.7 light-years away.
UV Ceti is a prototype flare star.
Gliese 1 is a red dwarf 14 light-years from Earth.
Kapteyn's Star is a high-velocity halo star.
